parts.text: A helium atom contains two protons, two neutrons and two electrons. Which particle in the helium atom is not charged?
markScheme: Answer: B - Neutrons have no charge

parts.text: Complete the sentence using a word from the box.
segments: The difference between an alpha particle and a helium atom is that the alpha particle does not have any
markScheme: 1 mark: electrons

parts.text: Which is a property of alpha particles? Tick one box.
options: Have a long range in air
markScheme: Answer: B - Alpha particles are highly ionising

parts.text: A lithium atom has 3 protons and 4 neutrons. What is the mass number of this lithium atom? Tick one box.
markScheme: Answer: C - Mass number = protons + neutrons = 3 + 4 = 7

parts.text: What is the atomic number of a lithium atom? Tick one box.
markScheme: Answer: A - Atomic number = number of protons = 3

parts.text: Complete the sentence using a word from the box.
segments: The electrons in an atom orbit in different energy
markScheme: 1 mark: levels

parts.text: Which of the following correctly describes the particles found in the nucleus of an atom?
markScheme: Answer: C - The nucleus contains neutrons and protons

parts.text: Complete the sentence using words from the box.
segments: An atom that loses an electron is called an
markScheme: 1 mark: ion
1 mark: positive

parts.text: A neutral atom has no overall charge. Explain why, in terms of its particles.
markScheme: 1 mark: The total **positive** charge (from protons) equals the total **negative** charge (from electrons)
1 mark: The number of **protons** equals the number of **electrons**

parts.text: Table 1 shows four discoveries about atoms. Which discovery was the earliest?
markScheme: Answer: B - The electron was discovered by J.J. Thomson in 1897, before the other discoveries

tables.caption: Four discoveries about atoms
rows: Atoms contain a small, dense, positively charged nucleus
Electrons orbit the nucleus at specific distances

parts.text: Which discovery in Table 1 was the most recent?
markScheme: Answer: C - The neutron was discovered by Chadwick in 1932, after the other discoveries

parts.text: The results of the alpha particle scattering experiment were reproducible. What does reproducible mean?
options: Other scientists can repeat the experiment and get the same results
The experiment can be done at a larger scale
The results prove the theory is correct
The equipment can be used for other experiments
markScheme: Answer: A - Reproducible means other scientists can repeat the experiment and obtain the same results

parts.text: In the plum pudding model of the atom, negative particles are embedded in a sphere of positive charge. What are these negative particles called?
markScheme: Answer: A - The negative particles embedded in the plum pudding model are electrons

parts.text: Which statement gives a reason why scientists decided that a scientific model of the atom needed replacing?
options: The model was difficult to understand
The model was over 100 years old
New experimental evidence contradicted the model
markScheme: Answer: C - Models are replaced when new experimental evidence does not fit the existing model

parts.text: Complete the sentences about atomic particles using words from the box.
segments: The particle with relative mass 1 and relative charge +1 is the
. The particle with very small relative mass and relative charge −1 is the
. The particle with relative mass 1 and relative charge 0 is the
markScheme: 1 mark: proton (relative mass 1, relative charge +1)
1 mark: electron (very small relative mass, relative charge −1)
1 mark: neutron (relative mass 1, relative charge 0)

parts.text: In the alpha particle scattering experiment, alpha particles were fired at a thin gold foil. Alpha particles and gold nuclei are both positively charged. Complete the sentences using words from the box.
segments: the alpha particles. As an alpha particle gets closer to the gold nucleus, the electric field strength experienced by the alpha particle
. As an alpha particle gets closer to the gold nucleus, the force experienced by the alpha particle
markScheme: 1 mark: repels
1 mark: increases (electric field strength)
1 mark: increases (force)

parts.text: In the alpha particle scattering experiment, most alpha particles passed straight through the gold foil. A small number were deflected slightly, and very few were deflected back. What can be deduced about the atom from the fact that most alpha particles passed straight through?
options: The atom contains protons, neutrons and electrons
The atom is mostly empty space
markScheme: Answer: C - Most alpha particles pass straight through because the atom is mostly empty space

parts.text: Three atoms are shown in Table 1. Two of the atoms are from the same element. Which of A, B and C is an atom of a different element? Give one reason for your answer.
markScheme: 1 mark: **B** is a different element
1 mark: B has a different number of **protons** (or a different atomic number)

parts.text: Two of the atoms A, B and C shown in Table 1 are isotopes of the same element. Which two are isotopes? Explain your answer.
markScheme: 1 mark: **A** and **C** are isotopes
1 mark: They have the same number of **protons** (same atomic number / same element)
1 mark: They have a different number of **neutrons** (different mass numbers)

parts.text: Doctors use nuclear radiation to diagnose illness. Table 1 gives data about three radiation sources. Each emits beta radiation. Explain why oxygen-15 is likely to pose the least risk to a patient.
markScheme: 1 mark: Oxygen-15 has the **shortest half-life** of the three sources
1 mark: So the patient is exposed to **radiation** for a shorter time / the source decays most quickly

parts.text: Radiation may be used to treat a patient if the risk from the radiation is...
options: Much bigger than the possible benefit
About the same as the possible benefit
Much smaller than the possible benefit
markScheme: Answer: C - Radiation is used when the risk is much smaller than the possible benefit

parts.text: Treating an illness with radiation may also harm a patient. State the risk from treating a patient with radiation.
markScheme: 1 mark: The radiation may **damage** / destroy / kill / mutate / ionise healthy body cells

parts.text: In the early 20th century, scientists used the 'plum pudding' model of the atom. Following the alpha particle scattering experiments by Rutherford and Marsden, the 'nuclear' model was suggested. Describe the differences between the plum pudding model and the nuclear model of the atom.
markScheme: 1 mark: In the nuclear model, the **mass is concentrated** at the centre in a small nucleus
1 mark: In the plum pudding model, mass is **spread evenly** throughout the atom
1 mark: In the nuclear model, **electrons orbit** the nucleus at a distance
1 mark: In the plum pudding model, electrons are **embedded** in the sphere of positive charge

parts.text: How is the Bohr model of the atom different from the nuclear model of the atom?
markScheme: 1 mark: In the Bohr model, electrons orbit at **specific distances** (fixed energy levels / shells), whereas in the nuclear model electrons can orbit at **any distance**

parts.text: In the alpha particle scattering experiment, alpha particles were directed at a thin gold foil. Most passed straight through, but some were deflected through large angles. Explain why some alpha particles are deflected through large angles.
markScheme: 1 mark: Both the alpha particle and the gold **nucleus** are **positively** charged
1 mark: So they **repel** each other, deflecting the alpha particle

parts.text: Two alpha particles, B and C, pass near a gold nucleus. Alpha particle B passes closer to the nucleus than alpha particle C. Explain why alpha particle B is deflected more than alpha particle C.
markScheme: 1 mark: Alpha particle B passes **closer** to the (positively charged) nucleus
1 mark: So it experiences a **stronger** repulsive (electrostatic) force

parts.text: Electrons in an atom can move between energy levels. Explain how an electron moves to a higher energy level and how it moves to a lower energy level.
markScheme: 1 mark: To move to a higher energy level, an electron must **absorb** electromagnetic radiation (or a specific amount of energy / a photon)
1 mark: To move to a lower energy level, an electron **emits** electromagnetic radiation (or releases energy as a photon)
